SL: My name is Sarah Lister and I am a Senior
Lecturer in Primary Languages.

12.text:
PP: Hi, I'm Pauline Palmer. I'm a Senior Lecturer
in Primary Mathematics.

16.text:
SL: CLIL stands for 'Content and Language
Integrated Learning', which essentially is

21.text:
a dual focused approach where it is content
driven, not language driven.

29.text:
Some of our work this year have involved setting
up, planning and delivering a series of four

34.text:
CPD workshops to a number of Primary teachers.
This has involved looking at aspects of the

41.text:
Primary Mathematics curriculum, and how we
can actually teach that through French. So,

46.text:
what we have been doing really is looking
to explore some of the synergies between Mathematics

51.text:
and Modern Foreign Languages; some of which
are that Mathematics and MFL are often perceived

58.text:
as tricky subjects, subjects that teachers
and children find difficult. But also that

68.text:
we've really begun to explore this idea that
mathematics being a languages in itself, and

75.text:
looking at how we can also capitalise and
utilise the two pedagogies. So for example,

83.text:
from a Modern Foreign Languages perspective,
what we've been looking to embed in these

87.text:
workshops sessions are some of the techniques
and approaches that are very much common practice

94.text:
within a discreet, traditional language teaching
lessons. So, things like repetition, drilling.

102.text:
We have an approach that we call the ‘three
P's’. So, it is Present, Practice, Produce,

107.text:
so there is that sense of development within
a language lesson.

112.text:
PP: In terms of the Mathematics pedagogy,
as Sarah said, there are synergies. But for

117.text:
Mathematics we see as important a positive
attitude, but it is also the use of language

123.text:
in the mathematics classroom and getting learners
to use the language. So, the repetition and

129.text:
use of key vocabulary helps, as does the fact
that if you are teaching using the CLIL approach,

134.text:
you’re using a second language, you own
language input in actually quite restricted.

141.text:
You are more or less sticking to a script
and actually, sometimes that can be really

145.text:
helpful for learners because, sometimes, teachers
with the best will in the world put in anecdotes

151.text:
and illustrate their points and actually can
make the meaning less clear to learners. So,

158.text:
it kind of keeps things focused using a second
language. The other thing in Mathematics pedagogy

164.text:
that is really important is using practical
resources. The practical provides something

170.text:
people can build on and visualise and develop
some sort of memory, and accompanying that

177.text:
the language to go with it. And CLIL actually
provides that repetition, the use of the practical

183.text:
and the use of the visual to reinforce key
ideas.

186.text:
SL: The other aspect is really thinking about
how can we provide that meaningful and that

192.text:
purposeful content for language learning and
again, that is something that CLIL provides.

197.text:
PP: There have been benefits for us in terms
of working collaboratively. I think I'm conscious

204.text:
that we were both very much outside of our
comfort zone. I certainly was. I’ve not

208.text:
done any French for a very long time and I
wasn’t very good at it when I did it. So,

214.text:
it has been quite scary but it has been really
interesting.

219.text:
I think the other thing is it is always great
to see another colleague at work and very

223.text:
often, because of timetabling, we are really
us and a class of students, whereas this has

229.text:
been a genuine opportunity to team-teach,
build on each other’s strengths, to extent

234.text:
each other’s own understanding of the respective
subjects in forging something new. So, I think

240.text:
it has been a learning experience from that
point of view and certainly one that I could

246.text:
recommend in terms of peer support for teaching,
which I know we are all encouraged to engage

250.text:
with. It has actually felt meaningful because
we have been supporting each other and we've

255.text: both gained and grown from it.
